"This picture book is a disturbing story about a Nepalese girl who is taken to India and sold to a brothel. It is suitable as reading material for anyone over ten years old. Although it is designed as a self-reading material, it is better if it is used in a group situation. If parents, teachers or helpers can read this book with groups of children it can be more beneficial."
About child prostitution in India.

112.heading: Pauer, Frank, 1952-
112.title: Billy Ireland
112.author: Lucy Shelton Caswell ; graphic design by Frank Pauer.
notes: 2nd ed.
Includes bibliographical references.

Summary (from SkyRiver): Billy Ireland (1880-1935), a native of Chillicothe, Ohio, was hired by the Columbus Dispatch shortly after his high school graduation in 1898. A self-taught cartoonist, he worked for the Dispatch until his death and was famous both for his editorial cartoons and for his Sunday feature The Passing Show.

Summary (from publisher via SkyRiver): "Montrealer Michel Rabagliati returns to the childhood story of his famous semi-autobiographical character. It's 1970 and Paul's family watches the news with anxiety as bombs are going off around Montreal. But Paul is more interested in flying his kite, comics, and his first kiss. Soon Paul joins the Scouts and heads off to camp. Away from his parents and extended family he discovers self worth in a troop of like-minded and enthusiastic boys. Things take a turn, however, when the troop gets mixed up in the terrifying events of the FLQ crisis. Paul Joins the Scouts is a coming of age story which takes an historical approach to both the Baden Powell scouting movement and the October Crisis, but humanizes these incidents for both a YA and adult audience. It is original, sincere, captivating, and a little bit retro."
